title: Celtic and Rangers demonstrate the strength of Scottish football in Europe ahead of weekend of league action
text:
Like the outcome of Brexit, predictions about the possible fortunes of the Old Firm in Europe are fraught with hazard but, at the midway point of their Europa League group stage campaigns, both Celtic and Rangers are well placed to extend their participation beyond Christmas.

Celtic’s resounding home win over Lazio on Thursday put the Scottish champions a point clear at the top of Group E, one point ahead of CFR Cluj and four clear of the Serie A side, who were top seeds. The Hoops’ next fixture takes them to Rome, where a draw would be of great significance to Neil Lennon and his players.​

Rangers, meanwhile, are second in Group G, two points behind Young Boys and ahead of Porto on goal difference. They are, in fact, a point worse off than at the same stage last year but this time they have two home games in the second half of their campaign, against Young Boys and Porto.​

There are other variables to be taken into account but, so far, the Glasgow pair have bolstered Scotland’s club competition coefficient with the potential to cut next year’s qualifying process from four rounds to three. ​

“The four qualifiers are a marathon and if you can take one away then great, but even three qualifiers is a big ask,” Lennon said.​

“We want to get the coefficient up. At the minute though, all I’m thinking about is trying to get through the group and then take it from there.​

“I don’t believe that the Champions League is way beyond any Scottish club. In time, we will be there again and challenging and, hopefully, breaking the ceiling of the last 16 again.​

“Both teams are in the Europa League at the minute and performing very well. It’s the competition we are in so we have to maximise what we have.”​

Celtic’s meeting with Lazio was foreshadowed by fears of trouble from the visitors’ notorious Ultra support but the occasion turned out to be the celebration of football Lennon had anticipated, adding to his enjoyment of an absorbing contest won by fine goals from Ryan Christie and Christopher Jullien and secured by Fraser Forster’s superlative saves from Marco Parolo and Dario Cataldi.​
description: Like the outcome of Brexit, predictions about the possible fortunes of the Old Firm in Europe are fraught with hazard but, at the midway point of their Europa League group stage campaigns, both Celtic and Rangers are well placed to extend their participation beyond Christmas.
